overview: First cases of pneumonia of unknown cause reported in Wuhan, China.
furtherDescription: Chinese authorities notified the World Health Organization (WHO) of several pneumonia cases in Wuhan, Hubei Province. The cause was later identified as a novel coronavirus.

overview: WHO declares a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC).
furtherDescription: The WHO issued its highest alert level, acknowledging the international spread of COVID-19 and urging coordinated global action.

overview: First confirmed COVID-19 death outside China in the Philippines.
furtherDescription: A 44-year-old man in the Philippines became the first recorded COVID-19 fatality outside China, highlighting global spread concerns.

overview: WHO declares COVID-19 a global pandemic.
furtherDescription: The WHO officially characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic, acknowledging sustained global transmission and the need for urgent containment measures.

overview: Global lockdowns and travel restrictions implemented.
furtherDescription: Many countries introduced strict lockdowns and border closures to contain the virus, drastically reducing global mobility and economic activity.

overview: Development and trials of COVID-19 vaccines begin worldwide.
furtherDescription: Pharmaceutical companies and research institutions launched large-scale vaccine trials, with mRNA technology showing early promise.

overview: First COVID-19 vaccine approved for emergency use in the UK (Pfizer-BioNTech).
furtherDescription: The UK became the first country to approve an mRNA-based COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use, marking a major milestone in the pandemic response.

overview: Global vaccination campaigns accelerate through 2021.
furtherDescription: Countries rolled out mass vaccination programs, though disparities in access between high- and low-income nations became apparent.

overview: Emergence of the Delta and Omicron variants.
furtherDescription: New, more transmissible variants of SARS-CoV-2 drove fresh waves of infection, challenging global vaccination efforts.

overview: WHO declares end of COVID-19 as a global public health emergency.
furtherDescription: After more than three years, the WHO declared the COVID-19 emergency phase over, citing widespread immunity and reduced mortality.

overview: Pfizer and Moderna announce over 90% efficacy in COVID-19 vaccine trials.
furtherDescription: Both Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna reported high efficacy rates in Phase 3 clinical trials, marking a breakthrough in vaccine development.

overview: Global COVID-19 cases surpass 100 million.
furtherDescription: By January 2021, total confirmed COVID-19 cases worldwide exceeded 100 million, according to Johns Hopkins University data.

overview: US surpasses 1 million COVID-19 deaths.
furtherDescription: The United States reached the grim milestone of 1 million deaths, reflecting the pandemic’s ongoing toll despite vaccines.

overview: The Delta variant becomes the dominant global strain.
furtherDescription: The highly transmissible Delta variant spread rapidly worldwide, causing renewed outbreaks even in highly vaccinated regions.

overview: Omicron variant discovered in South Africa and declared a Variant of Concern.
furtherDescription: WHO designated Omicron as a Variant of Concern due to its high number of mutations and rapid global spread.

overview: Global COVID-19 deaths surpass 5 million.
furtherDescription: WHO reported that global deaths attributed to COVID-19 had exceeded 5 million, underscoring its vast human cost.

overview: China ends its zero-COVID policy after nearly three years.
furtherDescription: The Chinese government abruptly ended strict zero-COVID lockdowns and mass testing, leading to widespread outbreaks.

overview: Long COVID recognized as a global health concern.
furtherDescription: Researchers and health agencies identified post-acute COVID-19 symptoms — 'Long COVID' — as a chronic public health issue.

overview: WHO releases updated global vaccination strategy.
furtherDescription: WHO urged nations to increase vaccine coverage to 70% of global population, prioritizing vulnerable groups and boosters.

overview: WHO establishes the 'Pandemic Accord' framework to prepare for future pandemics.
furtherDescription: Member states began drafting a global agreement to strengthen preparedness and equitable response mechanisms for future outbreaks.
